Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: A lot of history about empires, how to think more critically about the world and history, and how to live a more aware life.
I learned how to improve my writing skills and how to write college-level analytical essays.

I developed a great amount of writing skills from this course. I have always thought that my argumentative writing skills had needed improvement, and I truly believe that this course allowed me to better myself as a writer.
My writing skills along with my time management improved significantly in my opinion.

I learned about the power dynamics associated with consumption, both metaphoric and literal. It helped me to make connections between past imperialism and the police brutality and race relations of today.

I learned to be more open-minded and to question things in life that we often believe are set up to be a certain way. This class was very empowering and through the discussions, I learned so much from my peers' experiences and thoughts.

I expected to improve my writing skills in this English 114 course, and I did feel improvement from the extensive and nuanced feedback the instructor, Anusha, gave and how accessible she was. What I didn't expect was how compelling all the readings and discussions were, and the sheer diversity of issues we covered in this class that was focused on empires' myriad ways of consumption over multiple facets of human lives. It is one of the more meaningful classes I have ever taken.

Strengths: This course is very engaging, and you walk away knowing more regardless of your knowledge base going in.

Weaknesses: Could be slightly clearer about what you're learning from the title of the course?
A strength of this course is the seminar-style in which it was taught, which encouraged thoughtful discussions.
I thought that the readings and essay prompts were very interesting and not only kept the class engaged, but also sparked great discussion.
Strength: will definitely help with your writing, regardless of year or level in writing
The small class size was a huge strength of the course. It required everyone to be engaged with the material and come up with their own opinions and connections.

This course is very helpful to students who are seeking to become better writers. This class allowed me to articulate my claims and arguments better as well as expand my views and be logical throughout my writing.

I loved how what we learned in this class mattered in the real world and that we could carry the lessons with us outside of class. All the readings were thoroughly thought-provoking and impactful. The units logically connected together thematically, and it was great that we contextualized individual readings within the larger framework of "Eating the Empire." One thing that could be improved, however, is how we did the peer revisions in class. The handout's, while useful as a guide, ended up impeding useful student feedback because it was so long and had so many components.
Yes. The course really is Woke 101 and helps you live your life better as well as learn a lot of history / writing skills!
Yes, besides learning how to write well, the content of this course is very interesting and useful to know.
Yes, I would recommend. For any student looking to improve writing skills and become engaged in interesting discussion about a wide variety of topics, this is a great course to take.
This course is more than just a writing course. The readings and the discussions in class will expand your perspective, and the professor is very open to new ideas.
